definition_introduction.name: Definition and Introduction
definition_introduction.content:
Introduction to Statistics

Definition of Statistics

Statistics is the science of collecting, organizing, presenting, analyzing, and interpreting numerical data for the purpose of making decisions and drawing conclusions.

Statistics can be defined in two ways:

  • Plural sense: Statistics refers to numerical facts or data collected systematically (e.g., statistics of population, unemployment, etc.)
  • Singular sense: Statistics refers to the methods and techniques used to collect, analyze, and interpret data.

Definition of Terms Commonly Used in Statistics

Data: Raw facts and figures that are collected for analysis. Example: heights of students: 1.6m, 1.7m, 1.8m, 1.65m.

Variable: A characteristic or attribute that can assume different values. Examples: height, weight, age, gender.

Population: The complete collection of all items or individuals under consideration. Example: All registered voters in Nigeria.

Sample: A subset of the population selected for study. Example: 1000 randomly selected voters from Nigeria.

Parameter: A numerical value that describes a characteristic of a population. Example: The average height of all Nigerian men (population mean μ).

Statistic: A numerical value that describes a characteristic of a sample. Example: The average height of 500 sampled Nigerian men (sample mean x̄).

Census: The collection of data from every member of a population.

Sampling: The process of selecting a sample from a population.

Descriptive Statistics

Descriptive statistics involves methods for organizing, summarizing, and presenting data in a meaningful way. It includes:

  • Tabulation (frequency tables)
  • Graphical representations (charts, graphs)
  • Numerical measures (mean, median, mode, standard deviation, etc.)

Example: Calculate the mean of 5, 8, 12, 15, 20.

Solution: Mean = (5 + 8 + 12 + 15 + 20)/5 = 60/5 = 12

Inferential Statistics

Inferential statistics involves methods for drawing conclusions about a population based on information from a sample. It includes:

  • Estimation (point and interval estimates)
  • Hypothesis testing
  • Regression analysis
  • Correlation analysis

Example: From a sample of 100 students, the average height is 1.68m with standard deviation 0.1m. Estimate the population average height with 95% confidence interval:

Confidence interval = x̄ ± 1.96 × (s/√n) = 1.68 ± 1.96 × (0.1/10) = 1.68 ± 0.0196 = (1.6604, 1.6996)m

Application of Statistics

Statistics is applied in various fields: Business and Economics, Science and Engineering, Medicine and Health, Social Sciences, Government, Agriculture, Sports.

Importance of Statistics

  1. Decision Making under uncertainty
  2. Prediction and Forecasting
  3. Comparison between groups
  4. Measurement of Uncertainty
  5. Policy Formulation
  6. Scientific Research validation

Variables, Random Variables and Data

Variable: Any characteristic that can take different values. Examples: age, gender, income, height.

Random Variable: A variable whose numerical value is determined by the outcome of a random experiment.

Data can be:

  • Qualitative (Categorical): Non-numerical data representing categories (e.g., gender: male/female, color: red/blue/green)
  • Quantitative (Numerical): Numerical data that can be measured (e.g., height: 1.6m, 1.7m; weight: 60kg, 65kg)

The Four Levels of Measurement

Nominal Scale: Categories with no order or ranking. Examples: gender (male/female), religion (Christian/Muslim), marital status (single/married).

Properties: Classification only. No arithmetic operations possible.

Ordinal Scale: Categories with natural order, but differences not measurable. Examples: educational level (primary < secondary < tertiary), letter grades (A > B > C).

Properties: Classification and order, but no meaningful differences.

Interval Scale: Ordered categories with equal intervals, but no true zero. Examples: temperature in Celsius (0°C does not mean no temperature), IQ scores.

Properties: Classification, order, equal intervals. Addition and subtraction are meaningful, multiplication and division are not.

Ratio Scale: Ordered categories with equal intervals and true zero. Examples: height (0 cm means no height), weight, age, income.

Properties: Classification, order, equal intervals, true zero. All arithmetic operations are meaningful.

Calculation Example: With ratio data, we can say: Person A weighs 80kg, Person B weighs 40kg. A is twice as heavy as B. With interval data (temperature 20°C vs 10°C), we cannot say 20°C is twice as hot as 10°C.

Types of Random Variables

Discrete Random Variable: Can take only a countable number of distinct values.

Example: Number of students in a class: could be 20, 21, 22, ... but not 20.5.

Probability distribution example: Tossing a fair coin twice, let X = number of heads.

P(X=0) = 1/4, P(X=1) = 1/2, P(X=2) = 1/4

Continuous Random Variable: Can take any value within a given interval.

Example: Height of students: can be 1.65m, 1.651m, 1.6512m, etc.

For continuous variables, probability of exact value is zero. We calculate probability over intervals.

Types of Statistical Data by Source

Primary Data: Data collected directly from the source by the investigator.

Examples: Survey responses, experiment measurements, interviews.

Secondary Data: Data already collected by someone else and available for use.

Examples: Census data, published reports, government statistics.

Methods of Collection of Data

Direct Observation: Investigator observes and records without interaction.

Example: Counting number of cars passing an intersection from 8am-9am: 342 cars observed.

Interviewing: Asking questions directly to respondents.

Example: Interviewing 50 farmers about their crop yields. Results: average yield = 2.5 tons/hectare.

Questionnaire: Set of questions sent to respondents to fill out themselves.

Example: Survey of 200 customers: 120 satisfied (60%), 50 neutral (25%), 30 dissatisfied (15%).

Abstractions From Published Statistics: Extracting data from existing sources.

Example: Obtaining GDP growth rates from World Bank database: 2019: 2.3%, 2020: -3.1%, 2021: 5.2%.

summarization_presentation.name: Presentation of Data
summarization_presentation.content:
Presentation of Data

Introduction

After data are collected, they need to be organized, summarized, and presented in a meaningful way to reveal patterns, trends, and relationships. The two main methods are:

  • Tabular Method: Arranging data in tables
  • Graphical Method: Presenting data using charts and graphs

Purpose of Tabulation

Tabulation is the process of arranging data in rows and columns. Purposes include:

  1. To simplify complex data
  2. To facilitate comparison
  3. To reveal patterns and trends
  4. To save space and time
  5. To provide a basis for statistical analysis

Features of a Table

  1. Table Number: Every table should have a number for identification (e.g., Table 1, Table 2).
  2. Title: A clear, concise title describing the content of the table. It should answer: what, where, when.
  3. Headnotes: Explanatory notes placed below the title.
  4. Stubs: Row headings that identify items in each row.
  5. Captions: Column headings that describe data in each column.
  6. Body: The main part containing the actual data.
  7. Footnote: Explanatory notes at the bottom explaining exceptions.
  8. Source: Indicates where data were obtained from.
  9. Units of Measurement: Should be clearly indicated.

Construction of a Frequency Table

A frequency table organizes data by showing how many times each value or category occurs.

Example: The following are marks (out of 50) of 30 students in a test:

45, 32, 28, 35, 41, 38, 32, 29, 31, 27, 38, 42, 36, 33, 31, 39, 44, 37, 34, 30, 41, 36, 33, 29, 38, 40, 35, 37, 42, 39

Steps in constructing a frequency table:

  1. Arrange data in ascending order:

    27, 28, 29, 29, 30, 31, 31, 32, 32, 33, 33, 34, 35, 35, 36, 36, 37, 37, 38, 38, 38, 39, 39, 40, 41, 41, 42, 42, 44, 45

  2. Determine the range:

    Range = Maximum value - Minimum value = 45 - 27 = 18

  3. Decide on the number of classes (k):

    Using Sturges' rule: k = 1 + 3.322 log n, where n = 30

    k = 1 + 3.322 log 30 = 1 + 3.322 × 1.477 = 1 + 4.91 = 5.91 ≈ 6 classes

  4. Determine the class interval width:

    Class width = Range/k = 18/6 = 3

  5. Set up the class boundaries:

    Starting from 27: 27-29, 30-32, 33-35, 36-38, 39-41, 42-44, 45-47

    But to avoid gaps, we use class boundaries: 26.5-29.5, 29.5-32.5, 32.5-35.5, 35.5-38.5, 38.5-41.5, 41.5-44.5, 44.5-47.5

  6. Complete the frequency table

Calculations:

  • Class Mark (x) = (Lower limit + Upper limit)/2
  • For 27-29: x = (27+29)/2 = 56/2 = 28
  • For 30-32: x = (30+32)/2 = 62/2 = 31, etc.
  • Cumulative frequency: Running total of frequencies
  • Relative frequency = f/Σf = f/30
  • Percentage frequency = Relative frequency × 100%

Graphical Descriptions of Data

Pie Chart

A circular chart divided into sectors where each sector represents a category. The angle of each sector = (frequency/total) × 360°.

Example: Using the frequency table to calculate angles for pie chart:

ClassFrequencyAngle = (f/30) × 360°
27-294(4/30) × 360 = 48°
30-325(5/30) × 360 = 60°
33-35560°
36-387(7/30) × 360 = 84°
39-41560°
42-443(3/30) × 360 = 36°
45-471(1/30) × 360 = 12°
Total30360°

Bar Chart

Rectangular bars represent the frequency or percentage of each category.

Simple Bar Chart: For the frequency distribution above, draw bars of height equal to frequencies (4,5,5,7,5,3,1) for each class.

Multiple Bar Chart Example: Compare sales of three products across four quarters:

QuarterProduct AProduct BProduct C
Q1453852
Q2524148
Q3484455
Q4555060

For each quarter, draw three bars side by side representing the three products.

Component Bar Chart

Single bar divided into segments representing components.

Example: Expenditure breakdown for a family per month:

ItemAmount (₦)Percentage
Food50,00033.3%
Rent30,00020.0%
Transport20,00013.3%
Education25,00016.7%
Others25,00016.7%
Total150,000100%

A single bar of height 150,000 is divided into segments of heights 50,000, 30,000, 20,000, 25,000, 25,000.

Histogram

A bar chart with bars drawn without gaps, representing continuous data. The area of each bar is proportional to the frequency.

Example: From our frequency table, draw a histogram with class boundaries on x-axis and frequencies on y-axis. Bars: 26.5-29.5 (height 4), 29.5-32.5 (height 5), etc.

For unequal class intervals, use frequency density = frequency/class width.

Example with unequal intervals:

ClassFrequencyClass WidthFrequency Density
0-1015101.5
10-2025102.5
20-3030103.0
30-5040202.0
50-8030301.0

In histogram, bar heights are frequency densities: 1.5, 2.5, 3.0, 2.0, 1.0. Areas = frequency density × width = frequency.

Frequency Polygon

A line graph connecting the midpoints (class marks) of each class at their corresponding frequencies.

Construction: Plot class marks (28, 31, 34, 37, 40, 43, 46) against frequencies (4, 5, 5, 7, 5, 3, 1). Connect points with straight lines. Extend ends to x-axis at 25 (class mark before first) and 49 (class mark after last) with zero frequency.

Ogive or Cumulative Frequency Curve

Less than Ogive: Plot cumulative frequencies against upper class boundaries.

Upper BoundaryCumulative Frequency
29.54
32.59
35.514
38.521
41.526
44.529
47.530

More than Ogive: Plot cumulative frequencies (from top) against lower class boundaries.

Lower BoundaryCumulative Frequency (More than)
26.530
29.526
32.521
35.516
38.59
41.54
44.51

The intersection of the two ogives gives the median. From our data, median ≈ 36.5.

Basic Definitions

Class Interval: The range of values included in a class. Example: 27-29

Class Limits: The smallest and largest values in a class. Example: lower limit = 27, upper limit = 29

Class Boundaries: The actual limits separating classes, eliminating gaps. Example: 26.5-29.5

Class Mark (Midpoint): The average of upper and lower class limits. Example: (27+29)/2 = 28

Class Width: The difference between consecutive lower class limits or between class boundaries. Example: 30 - 27 = 3 or 29.5 - 26.5 = 3

Frequency Density: Frequency divided by class width. Used when class intervals are unequal.

measures_central_tendency.name: Measures of Central Tendency
measures_central_tendency.content:
Measures of Location / Central Tendency

Measures of Central Tendency

Measures of central tendency (averages) are single values that represent the center or typical value of a distribution.

Characteristics of a Good Average

  1. Rigorously Defined: Clear and unambiguous definition
  2. Easy to Understand: Simple to comprehend and calculate
  3. Based on All Observations: Uses all data points
  4. Not Affected by Extreme Values: Resistant to outliers
  5. Capable of Further Algebraic Treatment: Usable in further analysis
  6. Stability: Not vary much between samples
  7. Easy to Interpret: Meaningful and easy to explain

Types of Average

Arithmetic Mean (A.M)

The arithmetic mean is the sum of all values divided by the number of values.

For Ungrouped Data:

Population mean: μ = Σx/N

Sample mean: x̄ = Σx/n

Example 1 (Ungrouped): Find the mean of 8, 12, 15, 20, 25.

Solution: Σx = 8+12+15+20+25 = 80, n = 5, x̄ = 80/5 = 16

Example 2: The heights (in cm) of 10 students are: 162, 165, 168, 170, 172, 175, 168, 170, 165, 169. Find the mean height.

Solution: Σx = 162+165+168+170+172+175+168+170+165+169 = 1684, n = 10, x̄ = 168.4 cm

For Grouped Data:

x̄ = Σfx/Σf where f is frequency and x is class mark.

Example 3 (Grouped Data): Calculate the mean from the following frequency distribution:

ClassFrequency (f)Class Mark (x)fx
0-105525
10-20815120
20-301225300
30-40735245
40-50345135
TotalΣf = 35Σfx = 825

x̄ = Σfx/Σf = 825/35 = 23.57

Example 4 (Step Deviation Method): Using assumed mean A = 25 (class mark of 20-30) and class width c = 10:

Classfxd = (x-A)/cfd
0-1055(5-25)/10 = -2-10
10-20815(15-25)/10 = -1-8
20-301225(25-25)/10 = 00
30-40735(35-25)/10 = 17
40-50345(45-25)/10 = 26
Total35-5

x̄ = A + c × (Σfd/Σf) = 25 + 10 × (-5/35) = 25 + 10 × (-0.1429) = 25 - 1.429 = 23.57

Properties of Arithmetic Mean:

  • Sum of deviations from mean is zero: Σ(x - x̄) = 0
  • Check: For Example 1, deviations: (8-16)=-8, (12-16)=-4, (15-16)=-1, (20-16)=4, (25-16)=9; sum = -8-4-1+4+9 = 0
  • Sum of squared deviations is minimum when taken from mean
  • Affected by extreme values: For data 2,3,4,5,100, mean = 22.8, not representative

Weighted Arithmetic Mean: x̄_w = Σwx/Σw

Example 5: A student scored 70 in test (weight 30%), 80 in exam (weight 50%), and 90 in assignment (weight 20%). Calculate weighted mean.

x̄_w = (70×0.3 + 80×0.5 + 90×0.2)/(0.3+0.5+0.2) = (21 + 40 + 18)/1 = 79

The Median

The median is the middle value when data are arranged in order.

For Ungrouped Data:

  • If n is odd: Median = (n+1)/2th value
  • If n is even: Median = average of n/2th and (n/2 + 1)th values

Example 6 (odd n): Find median of 12, 5, 8, 15, 10.

Sorted: 5, 8, 10, 12, 15. n = 5, position = (5+1)/2 = 3. Median = 10

Example 7 (even n): Find median of 12, 5, 8, 15, 10, 7.

Sorted: 5, 7, 8, 10, 12, 15. n = 6, positions 3 and 4: values 8 and 10. Median = (8+10)/2 = 9

For Grouped Data:

Median = L + ((n/2 - cf)/f) × h

Where: L = lower boundary of median class, n = total frequency, cf = cumulative frequency before median class, f = frequency of median class, h = class width

Example 8: Using the frequency distribution from Example 3, find the median.

ClassFrequencyCumulative Frequency
0-1055
10-20813
20-301225
30-40732
40-50335

n/2 = 35/2 = 17.5. Median class is 20-30 (cf before = 13, f = 12).

L = 19.5 (lower boundary of 20-30), cf = 13, f = 12, h = 10

Median = 19.5 + ((17.5 - 13)/12) × 10 = 19.5 + (4.5/12 × 10) = 19.5 + 3.75 = 23.25

Properties of Median:

  • Not affected by extreme values: For 2,3,4,5,100, median = 4 (representative)
  • Can be used for ordinal data
  • Easy to understand and calculate
  • Not based on all observations
  • Not capable of algebraic treatment

The Mode

The mode is the value that occurs most frequently.

For Ungrouped Data: The value with highest frequency.

Example 9: Find mode of 5, 8, 5, 12, 8, 5, 10, 8, 8.

Frequency: 5 appears 3 times, 8 appears 4 times, others appear once. Mode = 8

Example 10 (Bimodal): 3,5,5,7,8,8,9. Modes = 5 and 8 (two modes)

For Grouped Data:

Mode = L + ((f₁ - f₀)/(2f₁ - f₀ - f₂)) × h

Where: L = lower boundary of modal class, f₁ = frequency of modal class, f₀ = frequency of class before modal class, f₂ = frequency of class after modal class, h = class width

Example 11: Using the frequency distribution from Example 3, find the mode.

Modal class is 20-30 (highest frequency = 12).

L = 19.5, f₁ = 12, f₀ = 8, f₂ = 7, h = 10

Mode = 19.5 + ((12-8)/(2×12 - 8 - 7)) × 10 = 19.5 + (4/(24 - 15)) × 10 = 19.5 + (4/9 × 10) = 19.5 + 4.44 = 23.94

Properties of Mode:

  • Not affected by extreme values
  • Can be used for nominal data (modal category)
  • Easy to understand
  • Not based on all observations
  • Not uniquely defined sometimes (bimodal/multimodal)

Geometric Mean (G.M)

The geometric mean is the nth root of the product of n values.

For Ungrouped Data: G.M = (x₁ × x₂ × ... × xₙ)^(1/n)

Alternatively, log G.M = (Σ log x)/n

Example 12: Find geometric mean of 2, 4, 8.

Method 1: Product = 2×4×8 = 64, G.M = 64^(1/3) = 4

Method 2: log x: log 2 = 0.3010, log 4 = 0.6021, log 8 = 0.9031, Σ log x = 1.8062, log G.M = 1.8062/3 = 0.6021, G.M = antilog 0.6021 = 4

For Grouped Data: log G.M = (Σ f log x)/Σf

Example 13: Calculate geometric mean from frequency distribution:

Classfxlog xf log x
5-153101.00003.0000
15-255201.30106.5050
25-357301.477110.3397
35-454401.60216.4084
45-551501.69901.6990
Total2027.9521

log G.M = 27.9521/20 = 1.3976, G.M = antilog 1.3976 = 25.0

Uses of Geometric Mean:

  • Average rates of change, growth rates, interest rates
  • Example: Investment grows by 10%, 20%, 15% over three years. Average growth rate = (1.10×1.20×1.15)^(1/3) - 1 = (1.518)^(1/3) - 1 = 1.149 - 1 = 14.9%

Properties: G.M ≤ A.M, equality when all values equal. Cannot be calculated if any value is zero or negative.

Harmonic Mean (H.M)

The harmonic mean is the reciprocal of the arithmetic mean of the reciprocals.

For Ungrouped Data: H.M = n / Σ(1/x)

Example 14: Find harmonic mean of 2, 4, 8.

Σ(1/x) = 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 = 0.5 + 0.25 + 0.125 = 0.875

H.M = 3/0.875 = 3.43

For Grouped Data: H.M = Σf / Σ(f/x)

Example 15: Using the frequency distribution from Example 13:

Classfxf/x
5-153100.3000
15-255200.2500
25-357300.2333
35-454400.1000
45-551500.0200
Total200.9033

H.M = 20/0.9033 = 22.14

Uses of Harmonic Mean:

  • Averaging rates, speeds: If you travel 60 km at 60 km/h and 60 km at 40 km/h, average speed = total distance/total time = 120/(1 + 1.5) = 120/2.5 = 48 km/h. Using harmonic mean: 2/(1/60 + 1/40) = 2/(0.01667 + 0.025) = 2/0.04167 = 48 km/h.

Properties: H.M ≤ G.M ≤ A.M, equality when all values equal. Cannot be calculated if any value is zero.

Example 16: Verify relationship for 2,4,8: A.M = 4.67, G.M = 4, H.M = 3.43, confirming A.M > G.M > H.M.

Empirical Relationship Between Mean, Median, and Mode

For a moderately skewed distribution: Mode = 3Median - 2Mean

Or Mean - Mode = 3(Mean - Median)

Example 17: From our grouped data: Mean = 23.57, Median = 23.25, Mode = 23.94

Check: 3Median - 2Mean = 3×23.25 - 2×23.57 = 69.75 - 47.14 = 22.61, not equal to 23.94 (distribution not perfectly symmetric)

This relationship helps identify skewness:

  • If Mean = Median = Mode: Symmetric distribution
  • If Mean > Median > Mode: Positively skewed (tail to right)
  • If Mean < Median < Mode: Negatively skewed (tail to left)

For our data: Mean (23.57) ≈ Median (23.25) < Mode (23.94), suggesting slight negative skew.

measures_dispersion.name: Measures of Partition and Dispersion
measures_dispersion.content:
Measures of Partition and Dispersion

Measures of Partition

Measures of partition divide a dataset into equal parts.

Quartiles

Quartiles divide data into four equal parts.

  • Q₁ (First Quartile): Value below which 25% of data fall (25th percentile)
  • Q₂ (Second Quartile): Median (50th percentile)
  • Q₃ (Third Quartile): Value below which 75% of data fall (75th percentile)

For Ungrouped Data:

Position of Q₁ = (n+1)/4, Q₂ = (n+1)/2, Q₃ = 3(n+1)/4

Example 1: Find Q₁, Q₂, Q₃ for data: 12, 5, 8, 15, 10, 7, 14, 9, 11, 13

Sorted: 5,7,8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15 (n=10)

Q₁ position = (10+1)/4 = 2.75 → average of 2nd and 3rd: (7+8)/2 = 7.5

Q₂ position = (10+1)/2 = 5.5 → average of 5th and 6th: (10+11)/2 = 10.5

Q₃ position = 3(10+1)/4 = 8.25 → average of 8th and 9th: (13+14)/2 = 13.5

For Grouped Data:

Q₁ = L + ((n/4 - cf)/f) × h

Q₂ = L + ((n/2 - cf)/f) × h (median)

Q₃ = L + ((3n/4 - cf)/f) × h

Example 2: Using frequency distribution from previous section:

ClassFrequencyCumulative Frequency
0-1055
10-20813
20-301225
30-40732
40-50335

n = 35, n/4 = 8.75, n/2 = 17.5, 3n/4 = 26.25

Q₁: Q₁ class is 10-20 (cf before = 5, f = 8)

L = 9.5, cf = 5, f = 8, h = 10

Q₁ = 9.5 + ((8.75 - 5)/8) × 10 = 9.5 + (3.75/8 × 10) = 9.5 + 4.6875 = 14.19

Q₂: (calculated earlier as median) = 23.25

Q₃: Q₃ class is 30-40 (cf before = 25, f = 7)

L = 29.5, cf = 25, f = 7, h = 10

Q₃ = 29.5 + ((26.25 - 25)/7) × 10 = 29.5 + (1.25/7 × 10) = 29.5 + 1.7857 = 31.29

Interquartile Range (IQR): Q₃ - Q₁ = 31.29 - 14.19 = 17.1

Quartile Deviation: (Q₃ - Q₁)/2 = 17.1/2 = 8.55

Deciles and Percentiles

Deciles: Divide data into 10 equal parts (D₁ to D₉). D₅ = median.

Percentiles: Divide data into 100 equal parts (P₁ to P₉₉). P₅₀ = median.

For grouped data: P_k = L + ((kn/100 - cf)/f) × h

Example 3: Find P₉₀ for the above distribution.

90% of 35 = 31.5. P₉₀ class is 40-50 (cf before = 32, f = 3)

L = 39.5, cf = 32, f = 3, h = 10

P₉₀ = 39.5 + ((31.5 - 32)/3) × 10 = 39.5 + (-0.5/3 × 10) = 39.5 - 1.67 = 37.83

Measures of Dispersion

Dispersion measures the spread or variability of data.

Range

Range = Maximum Value - Minimum Value

Example 4: For data 12, 5, 8, 15, 10, 7, 14, 9, 11, 13

Range = 15 - 5 = 10

Coefficient of Range: (Max - Min)/(Max + Min) = 10/(15+5) = 10/20 = 0.5

For grouped data: Range ≈ Upper boundary of last class - Lower boundary of first class

From Example 2: Range ≈ 49.5 - (-0.5) = 50, or using class marks: 45 - 5 = 40

Mean Deviation

Mean deviation is the average of absolute deviations from a central value.

For Ungrouped Data: MD = Σ|x - x̄|/n

Example 5: Calculate MD for data 48,49,50,51,52 (x̄ = 50)

|48-50|=2, |49-50|=1, |50-50|=0, |51-50|=1, |52-50|=2, Σ = 6, MD = 6/5 = 1.2

Example 6: Calculate MD for data 12,5,8,15,10,7,14,9,11,13 (x̄ = 10.5 from earlier)

Deviations: |12-10.5|=1.5, |5-10.5|=5.5, |8-10.5|=2.5, |15-10.5|=4.5, |10-10.5|=0.5, |7-10.5|=3.5, |14-10.5|=3.5, |9-10.5|=1.5, |11-10.5|=0.5, |13-10.5|=2.5

Σ = 1.5+5.5+2.5+4.5+0.5+3.5+3.5+1.5+0.5+2.5 = 26, MD = 26/10 = 2.6

For Grouped Data: MD = Σf|x - x̄|/Σf

Example 7: Using frequency distribution from earlier (x̄ = 23.57):

Classfx|x - x̄|f|x - x̄|
0-105518.5792.85
10-208158.5768.56
20-3012251.4317.16
30-4073511.4380.01
40-5034521.4364.29
Total35322.87

MD = 322.87/35 = 9.22

Coefficient of Mean Deviation: MD/x̄ = 9.22/23.57 = 0.391

Variance and Standard Deviation

Population Variance: σ² = Σ(x - μ)²/N

Sample Variance: s² = Σ(x - x̄)²/(n-1)

Standard Deviation: σ = √σ², s = √s²

For Ungrouped Data:

Example 8: Calculate variance and standard deviation for 48,49,50,51,52.

x̄ = 50

xx - x̄(x - x̄)²
48-24
49-11
5000
5111
5224
Total10

Sample variance s² = 10/(5-1) = 10/4 = 2.5

Sample standard deviation s = √2.5 = 1.58

Population variance σ² = 10/5 = 2, σ = √2 = 1.414

Example 9: Calculate for data 12,5,8,15,10,7,14,9,11,13 (x̄ = 10.5)

For Grouped Data: s² = [Σfx² - (Σfx)²/Σf] / (Σf - 1)

Example 10: Using frequency distribution from earlier:

Classfxfxx²fx²

Σfx = 825, Σfx² = 24075, Σf = 35

(Σfx)²/Σf = (825)²/35 = 680625/35 = 19446.43

Σfx² - (Σfx)²/Σf = 24075 - 19446.43 = 4628.57

s² = 4628.57/(35-1) = 4628.57/34 = 136.13

s = √136.13 = 11.67

Step Deviation Method: s = c × √[Σfd²/Σf - (Σfd/Σf)²]

Example 11: Using d = (x-25)/10 from earlier, with Σfd = -5, Σf = 35

Σfd² = 47, Σfd = -5, Σf = 35

Σfd²/Σf = 47/35 = 1.3429, (Σfd/Σf)² = (-5/35)² = (-0.1429)² = 0.0204

s = 10 × √(1.3429 - 0.0204) = 10 × √1.3225 = 10 × 1.15 = 11.5 (slight rounding difference)

Measures of Relative Dispersion

Coefficient of Variation (CV): CV = (s/x̄) × 100%

Example 12: Compare two datasets:

Dataset 1: Mean = 100, s = 10, CV = (10/100) × 100% = 10%

Dataset 2: Mean = 50, s = 8, CV = (8/50) × 100% = 16%

Dataset 1 has less relative variability (more consistent) despite larger absolute variability.

Example 13: For our grouped data: x̄ = 23.57, s = 11.67, CV = (11.67/23.57) × 100% = 49.5%

Coefficient of Quartile Deviation: (Q₃ - Q₁)/(Q₃ + Q₁) = 17.1/(31.29+14.19) = 17.1/45.48 = 0.376

Coefficient of Mean Deviation: MD/x̄ = 9.22/23.57 = 0.391

Empirical Rule

  • ≈ 68% of data within ±1σ of mean
  • ≈ 95% of data within ±2σ of mean
  • ≈ 99.7% of data within ±3σ of mean

Example 14: If scores are normally distributed with mean 70 and σ = 10, then:

68% score between 60 and 80

95% score between 50 and 90

99.7% score between 40 and 100

Chebyshev's Inequality

For any distribution, at least (1 - 1/k²) × 100% of data falls within k standard deviations of mean, for k > 1.

Example 15: For k = 2, at least 1 - 1/4 = 0.75 = 75% within ±2σ

For k = 3, at least 1 - 1/9 = 0.889 = 88.9% within ±3σ

For k = 4, at least 1 - 1/16 = 0.9375 = 93.75% within ±4σ

Example 16: For a distribution with mean 50 and σ = 5, at least 75% of data lies between 40 and 60 (k=2).
